title: SoC RTVF 372-0-20 Editing

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
"Once more I repeat, that editing is the creative force of filmic reality." - V. I. Pudovkin, 1929

Editing is considered by many to be the critical artistic expression of filmmaking; on par with dialogue, cinematography, even writing. In this class, you will take a crucial step towards your evolution as an editor of the moving image. We will do this in three ways:
We will read and discuss critical editing concepts, including the basic editing stages, practices and terminology. We will discuss how and why these different elements work to further the story and develop the vision of a film.
We will watch films and the discuss techniques employed, seeing the concepts we've discussed appear in film and analyzing their effectiveness.
you will work with uncut footage, both in exercises and longer projects, to develop these concepts and techniques for yourselves, becoming familiar with both concepts involved in executing them successfully. In the process, you will begin to develop your own style and voice as an editor.
You will be evaluated by quizzes, participation, exercises, and two major projects.

Materials:
Textbooks (required, approximately $50-$60): In the Blink of an Eye, (Walter Murch) and On Film Editing (Edward Dmytryk)
Hard drive (recommended, approximately $50-$100)
